cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who played the original wonder woman on tv
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine who played the original Wonder Woman on television, I need to recall the history of the character and the television series. The original Wonder Woman TV series aired in the 1970s. The actress who portrayed Wonder Woman in this series is well-known for her iconic role. I will consider the time period and the actress's impact on the character and pop culture.

Answer: Lynda Carter played the original Wonder Woman on TV.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who played the original wonder woman on tv
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Shannon Farnon (born November 28, 1941) is a Canadian actress and voice actress. She is best known as being the first actress to voice Wonder Woman in a Hanna-Barbera production.\n', 'Russell next appeared in "August Rush", released in November 2007. She also appeared on the cover of the "New York Post"s Page Six magazine on November 11, 2007. Russell later appeared in "Bedtime Stories". In an appearance on "The View" on December 15, 2008, Russell said she got the part because Adam Sandler\'s wife Jackie had seen her in "Waitress" and suggested her for the movie. Russell voiced Wonder Woman in a direct-to-video animated feature released March 3, 2009.\n', 'BULLET::::- Lynda Carter, American television actress who played "Wonder Woman" in the 1970s\n', 'Carter is most widely known as the star of the American live action television series "Wonder Woman", in the role of Diana Prince / Wonder Woman, based on the DC comic book fictional superheroine character of the same name, which aired on ABC and later on CBS from 1975 to 1979.\n', 'In 2017, Carter explained her perspective of portraying the Diana Prince/Wonder Woman character. Carter says she got the role back in 1975 largely because she looked the part, which was both a blessing and – as one of the show\'s producers warned her – a curse: "Oh, women are going be so jealous of you"... "Well, I said, \'Not a chance. They won\'t be, because I am not playing her that way. I want women to want to be me, or be my best friend!". As Carter describes Wonder Woman, "There is something about the character where in your creative mind for that time in your life where you pretended to be her, or whatever the situation was, that it felt like you could fly".\n', 'In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl named Drusilla appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger.\n', '"Katherine Lynch\'s Wonderwomen" began airing on 20 October 2008. It was the first production by WAKA TV, a company established by Lynch and Myler. The six-part series focused on the exploits of four characters, Singin\' Bernie Walsh, Sheila Sheik and two new characters, Liz Hurley and Dalkey Dunphy Davenport.\n', 'BULLET::::- In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger, in one of her first mass-media roles. The actress Charlene Tilton, best known for playing Lucy Ewing in the television series "Dallas", auditioned for the part of Wonder Girl but lost it to Winger. The pilot episode revealed that Wonder Woman\'s alter-ego, Princess Diana of Paradise Island, was Queen Hippolyta\'s daughter, but later episodes featured Diana\'s younger sibling, Drusilla. Drusilla first appeared in the two-part episode "The Feminum Mystique". In that episode, Queen Hippolyta (Carolyn Jones) sends Drusilla to America in order to bring Diana home to Paradise Island. (Queen Hippolyta is never referred to by name in any of the televised specials in which she appeared.) Drusilla gets tangled up in a Nazi plot to discover the secret of Wonder Woman\'s bracelets, which can deflect bullets, and in the process Drusilla masters the spinning transformation used by her older sister. Although Drusilla creates the persona of Wonder Girl, the distinction is lost on the Nazis, who believe her to be Wonder Woman and abduct her. In the second part of this episode, Drusilla returns to Paradise Island to help free her fellow Amazons from a Nazi overtaking. Drusilla appeared again in another episode, the final episode of the first season, entitled "Wonder Woman in Hollywood". On September 3, 1993, Winger appeared on the "Late Show with David Letterman" to promote her film "Wilder Napalm". There, Winger revealed she was contracted a position as a regular on the show and even the lead in a Wonder Girl spinoff TV show. She wanted off the show and had her agent get her out of her contract. Letterman then showed the audience a short clip of Winger as Wonder Girl and asked several questions about the show and co-star Lynda Carter. Winger briefly feigned embarrassment, but then claimed she was late for something she had to do, then surprisingly tore off her dress to reveal a Wonder Girl costume underneath. Winger ran through the audience to exit the theater, while the "Wonder Woman" theme song\'s bass line played.. In the comics, Drusilla was a regular amazon who appeared in Wonder Woman #182, 1969 who was an ally to Wonder Woman. A figure resembling Winger\'s Drusilla made a cameo appearance in "Infinite Crisis" #6, as the Wonder Girl of Earth-462. Cassandra Sandsmark would later adapt the alias of Drusilla to protect her identity.\n', 'However, in 1984, her prominent character was recast in "", when the role was given to Constance Caufield and later to B.J. Ward. This case has often been given as an example of injustice in the television and animation industry. Mary McDonald-Lewis voiced Wonder Woman in an episode of "Superman".\n', 'BULLET::::- "The New Adventures of Wonder Woman". In the 90 minute made-for-TV 1975 pilot movie, Lynda Carter as Wonder Woman fights Stella Stevens who plays the role of a Nazi spy. The previous year, an initial attempt to start a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby failed when it did not garner sufficient TV ratings for ABC Television to renew as a series. The movie was criticized for featuring the blonde-haired Crosby in the role traditionally reserved for a brunette, a decision that even Crosby had questioned. Crosby did have two short fights, one of which was against a renegade Amazon played by Anitra Ford.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

2. **Show Details**: The passages mention that the show aired from 1975 to 1979 on ABC and later on CBS. This contextualizes the time period during which Lynda Carter portrayed the character, indicating her significance in the history of television.

3. **Character Background**: The passages provide insight into the character of Wonder Woman, also known as Diana Prince, based on a DC comic book superheroine. Understanding the character's origins helps frame the cultural impact of Lynda Carter's portrayal.

It indicates that her performance was not just about the character's physical appearance but also about embodying empowerment and relatability for women.

6. **Other Characters**: The passages mention Debra Winger's role as Wonder Girl in the series, which adds context to the Wonder Woman franchise and its expansion into other characters. This information is relevant for understanding the broader narrative universe in which Wonder Woman exists.

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on the Original Wonder Woman on TV**

**Expert 1: Television Historian**
The television series "Wonder Woman," which aired from 1975 to 1979, is most famously associated with Lynda Carter, who portrayed the titular character, Diana Prince/Wonder Woman. Carter's performance is iconic and has defined the character for generations. The series was a significant cultural phenomenon, showcasing a strong female superhero at a time when such representations were rare.

**Expert 2: Animation Specialist**
While Lynda Carter is indeed the most recognized actress for the live-action portrayal, it's important to note that the character of Wonder Woman has been voiced by various actresses in animated productions. For instance, Shannon Farnon was the first to voice Wonder Woman in a Hanna-Barbera production. This highlights the character's versatility across different media and the evolution of her representation over time.

**Expert 3: Pop Culture Analyst**
Lynda Carter's portrayal was groundbreaking, but we should also consider the earlier attempts to adapt Wonder Woman for television. Cathy Lee Crosby starred in a 1974 pilot that ultimately failed to launch a series. This initial attempt faced criticism for not aligning with the traditional depiction of Wonder Woman, which may have contributed to its lack of success. The contrast between Crosby's portrayal and Carter's later success illustrates the importance of character fidelity in adaptations.

**Expert 4: Gender Studies Scholar**
Carter's portrayal of Wonder Woman was not just about the character's superpowers; it also involved a nuanced understanding of femininity and empowerment. Carter herself emphasized that she wanted women to see Wonder Woman as a role model rather than a figure of jealousy. This perspective adds depth to our understanding of how the character was received by audiences and the impact it had on women's representation in media.

**Points of Agreement:**
- All experts agree that Lynda Carter is the definitive portrayal of Wonder Woman in the live-action series.
- There is a consensus on the cultural significance of the character and the impact of her representation on audiences, particularly women.

**Points of Disagreement:**
- The extent to which earlier portrayals, like that of Cathy Lee Crosby, are relevant to the discussion varies among experts. Some argue that these attempts are crucial for understanding the evolution of the character, while others feel they detract from Carter's legacy.
- The focus on animated portrayals and voice acting is seen as less relevant by some, who prioritize live-action representations.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The discussion reveals that while Lynda Carter's portrayal of Wonder Woman is central to the character's legacy, it exists within a broader context of adaptations and interpretations. The failed pilot with Cathy Lee Crosby serves as a cautionary tale about character fidelity, while the contributions of voice actresses like Shannon Farnon highlight the character's adaptability across different media. Furthermore, the insights from gender studies emphasize the importance of representation and the cultural implications of Wonder Woman as a feminist icon.

In conclusion, the original Wonder Woman on TV, as embodied by Lynda Carter, is a multifaceted topic that encompasses various portrayals, cultural significance, and the evolution of female representation in media. This collaborative discussion enriches our understanding by integrating diverse perspectives, illustrating how the character of Wonder Woman has transcended her original comic book roots to become a symbol of empowerment and resilience.

The six-part series focused on the exploits of four characters, Singin' Bernie Walsh, Sheila Sheik and two new characters, Liz Hurley and Dalkey Dunphy Davenport.
', 'BULLET::::- In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger, in one of her first mass-media roles. The actress Charlene Tilton, best known for playing Lucy Ewing in the television series "Dallas", auditioned for the part of Wonder Girl but lost it to Winger. The pilot episode revealed that Wonder Woman's alter-ego, Princess Diana of Paradise Island, was Queen Hippolyta's daughter, but later episodes featured Diana's younger sibling, Drusilla. Drusilla first appeared in the two-part episode "The Feminum Mystique". In that episode, Queen Hippolyta (Carolyn Jones) sends Drusilla to America in order to bring Diana home to Paradise Island. (Queen Hippolyta is never referred to by name in any of the televised specials in which she appeared.) Drusilla gets tangled up in a Nazi plot to discover the secret of Wonder Woman's bracelets, which can deflect bullets, and in the process Drusilla masters the spinning transformation used by her older sister. Although Drusilla creates the persona of Wonder Girl, the distinction is lost on the Nazis, who believe her to be Wonder Woman and abduct her. In the second part of this episode, Drusilla returns to Paradise Island to help free her fellow Amazons from a Nazi overtaking. Drusilla appeared again in another episode, the final episode of the first season, entitled "Wonder Woman in Hollywood". On September 3, 1993, Winger appeared on the "Late Show with David Letterman" to promote her film "Wilder Napalm". There, Winger revealed she was contracted a position as a regular on the show and even the lead in a Wonder Girl spinoff TV show. She wanted off the show and had her agent get her out of her contract. Letterman then showed the audience a short clip of Winger as Wonder Girl and asked several questions about the show and co-star Lynda Carter. Winger briefly feigned embarrassment, but then claimed she was late for something she had to do, then surprisingly tore off her dress to reveal a Wonder Girl costume underneath. Winger ran through the audience to exit the theater, while the "Wonder Woman" theme song's bass line played.. In the comics, Drusilla was a regular amazon who appeared in Wonder Woman #182, 1969 who was an ally to Wonder Woman. A figure resembling Winger's Drusilla made a cameo appearance in "Infinite Crisis" #6, as the Wonder Girl of Earth-462. Cassandra Sandsmark would later adapt the alias of Drusilla to protect her identity.
', 'However, in 1984, her prominent character was recast in "", when the role was given to Constance Caufield and later to B.J. Ward. This case has often been given as an example of injustice in the television and animation industry. Mary McDonald-Lewis voiced Wonder Woman in an episode of "Superman".
', 'BULLET::::- "The New Adventures of Wonder Woman". In the 90 minute made-for-TV 1975 pilot movie, Lynda Carter as Wonder Woman fights Stella Stevens who plays the role of a Nazi spy. The previous year, an initial attempt to start a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby failed when it did not garner sufficient TV ratings for ABC Television to renew as a series. The movie was criticized for featuring the blonde-haired Crosby in the role traditionally reserved for a brunette, a decision that even Crosby had questioned. Crosby did have two short fights, one of which was against a renegade Amazon played by Anitra Ford.
']

2. **Series Background**: The series was based on the DC comic book character and aired on ABC and later on CBS. This context provides a historical framework for understanding the significance of Carter's role.
